definition: **noun / deck spec slang.** A **marketing claim that a turntable's measured rumble was below the instrument's noise-floor** — common ad lingo once quartz-locked direct-drives hit -70 dB or better. Emerged in the late 1970s when Japanese manufacturers like Technics, Denon, and Yamaha began producing direct-drive turntables with rumble specifications exceeding -70 dB DIN-B weighted, effectively making motor noise unmeasurable with standard audio test equipment of the era. The claim became a competitive talking point in spec-sheet wars, though critics noted that "zero rumble" was technically impossible — the measurement simply fell below the analyzer's -80 to -90 dB threshold. By the early 1980s, flagship models routinely advertised -78 dB or better, with some claiming "unmeasurable" performance. The term reflected both genuine engineering achievement (precision bearings, vibration isolation, heavy platters) and marketing hyperbole, as real-world listening conditions and cartridge sensitivity often revealed low-frequency noise that specs suggested didn't exist. Modern high-end turntables still chase ultra-low rumble figures, though the focus has shifted to actual audible performance rather than measurement-floor bragging rights.
etymology: Coined in late-1970s hi-fi advertising copy when direct-drive turntable rumble specifications began exceeding the measurement capabilities of standard audio test equipment, creating a marketing opportunity to claim "zero" or "unmeasurable" performance.
